It's been clear for a long time that this has nothing to do with supporting life and families. If it was, they'd respect us enough to let us make our own choices and they'd be bringing that same level of political might to the fight for moms and our kids.

What are they doing to make sure the mom has a safe and healthy pregnancy? What about once the kid is born? What are they doing about the full-on child care crisis? The mental health needs of the mom? Paid maternity leave? Paid family and sick leave to take care of our kids?

Just really disgusted by all of this. A small, small segment of this country will stop at nothing to stop people ‚Äî the majority of whom are already moms ‚Äî from having abortions. Meanwhile, what are they doing to support mothers and our kids?

This isn't getting much attention, but we're on the brink of one guy in Texas single-handedly outlawing the abortion pill mifepristone (aka the most common form of abortion care) in all 50 states. https://t.co/zl7gzYZTG0

In @FastCompany this week, I teamed up with @Carol_Juel, executive VP and chief technology and operating officer  at @Synchrony (a member of the @MomsFirstUS National Business Coalition for Child Care), to challenge the private sector to step up for moms. https://t.co/nITiOlXINZ

At @MomsFirstUS, we believe paid parental leave, child care, and equal pay aren't just "women's issues" or personal problems‚Äîthey're business issues. Because without child care, most moms can‚Äôt work. And lack of paid leave has led to moms leaving the workforce at historic rates.

Meanwhile, some companies are reneging on things like flexible work and childcare.

In other words: workplaces are at risk of going backwards, making it even harder to be a mom in the workforce.
Here's a sad fact: the percentage of companies that offered paid maternity leave beyond what the law requires fell from 53% in 2020 to just 35% last year.

This is great news, but we need to do more to make sure these women have the support to thrive at work when they graduate, especially if they choose to be moms.

So whether you are new to this movement or have been fighting alongside us all this time, now‚Äôs the time to join us. Start by following @MomsFirstUS and head over to https://t.co/ka3QRsxyPN to add your name to our mailing list.

To me, this new name is us building towards an even bigger movement. And that‚Äôs why I am proud and fired up that we finally have a name that captures the kind of culture shift we‚Äôve envisioned all this time.

So why did we change our name? Well, I believe that one of the things that‚Äôs so important in building movements is clarity in your mission. And believe it or not, the idea of putting moms first, just like girls who code, is oddly controversial. It's still quite radical.

A little over two years ago, I had an idea to help moms get out of crisis mode. I called it a Marshall Plan for Moms. Two years later, moms are still in crisis. But we are more organized than ever before.
Hi all, I have some big news: Marshall Plan for Moms is now Moms First (or @MomsFirstUS on social media)!

We've got big plans for 2023. Join us by following @WeAreMPM, and for those who are in a position to do so, consider making a contribution to help us build a grassroots movement to advocate for moms through affordable child care, paid leave, and equal pay: https://t.co/1AGkwdatpQ

In short: moms were in crisis, and yet no one was doing anything about it. We needed a plan. And I had a name for one. Since then, Marshall Plan for Moms (@WeAreMPM) has grown from an idea into a movement ‚Äî by moms, for moms. And we are just getting started.

Nearly a year into the pandemic, with schools and daycares still shuttered (even as bars re-opened), millions of women were pushed out of the labor force, erasing 30 years of progress overnight. As is so often the case, moms of color were disproportionately impacted.

So much going on I forgot that last week marked 2 years since @TheHill published my op-ed in which I first proposed a Marshall Plan for Moms, a plan to get moms help through policies like paid family leave, child care, equal pay, and yes, monthly checks.

We won't go backwards. Their bigotry and bullying is a danger to our children and our communities ‚Äî and plenty of moms agree with us. @WeAreMPM is building a movement to stop relentless attacks from these "parents rights" groups on our children, families, and communities.

Nationwide, groups like Moms for Liberty are leading efforts to ban books representing diverse perspectives, driving an extremist far-right agenda to control women, people of color, LGBTQ+ communities, anyone that does not maintain the white supremacist patriarchal status quo.
Thanks to the efforts of students, teachers, and parents in the community who organized and fought back, the ban has been defeated, for now.
In August 2021, the same list was distributed via email (under the subject line ‚ÄúBanned Resources‚Äù) to teachers with explicit instructions not to use the materials listed.

Hundreds of books, including ours, were assembled by educators on a list of diversity resources to help the community grapple with the racial and social turmoil following the murder of George Floyd. The school district then voted to ban the resources on that list from classrooms.
The @GirlsWhoCode book series was banned by the Central York School District ‚Äî and it‚Äôs disappointing that the district is not taking ownership of what happened there in 2020-2021.

I am glad to see this story continue to gain traction in the media, because the banning of books about girls learning to code ‚Äî in any school, for any amount of time ‚Äî is frankly terrifying. And for those who are asking if the books were ‚Äúreally‚Äù banned, they were. https://t.co/3QRteyvKFF

This past weekend made it very clear we can't sit by and let these "Moms for Liberty" and similar groups continue to get books banned in our schools and in our libraries.

Join our mailing list at https://t.co/o0NDuxa7NS and follow us for updates @WeAreMPM.

The fight does not end here. Our books being unbanned in Pennsylvania today does not protect them from being banned in Florida, or Texas, or anywhere else tomorrow. Even in Central York School District, there are people running for the school board who want to reinstate the ban.

Like I said, the organizing in Central York School District is nothing short of incredible. Teachers, students, parents banded together to mount a campaign to reverse this bigoted ban. Because of their determination, today the @GirlsWhoCode books are available in the district.

Even though these materials were intended for staff development and school libraries (i.e. not for curricular changes), these moms convinced the school board to ban a list of roughly 300 books they deemed "problematic", including the @GirlsWhoCode series.

In the aftermath of the murder of George Floyd and the racial reckoning of summer 2020, a group of so-called "activists" on the school board opposed educators‚Äô efforts to create a list of diversity resources for the school district.

So here's what I learned: for a 10-month period between 2020 and 2021, Central York School District did in fact remove the @GirlsWhoCode series, alongside other diverse children‚Äôs books from its classrooms.

First, you should know there are extraordinary people fighting these senseless book bans on the ground: teachers, students, parents, and school faculty who have been getting organized and ‚Äî in the case of the Central York School District in PA ‚Äî winning.

Thank you all for the support you showed this weekend as I learned our @GirlsWhoCode books had been banned. I spent the weekend digging into what happened, and have a few updates to share.

And in case you were wondering, working moms as a whole (aka moms of all races and ethnicities), on average, earn just 58 cents for every dollar working dads make. No surprise the pay gap is wider for Black moms compared to white moms.

Black women as a whole make just 58 cents for every dollar a white man makes. But for Black moms, the pay gap is even wider.

Black moms are paid just 52 cents to every dollar a white dad makes. That adds up to $2,825 each month. And $33,900 over the course of a year.

Every equal pay day, I've started to look at how the data breaks down for moms (and you should too).

Since today is #BlackWomensEqualPayDay, here's some background info on how Black moms are impacted by what's known as the "motherhood penalty."

This #MomsEqualPayDay, let us first acknowledge the true nature of the pay gap. And let us continue to build our pro-mom movement. Looking for a place to start? Join us at https://t.co/o0NDuxrJcs.

So not only do moms deal with the challenges of childcare (or lack thereof), insufficient paid leave, misogyny in the workplace, and all the barriers we think of that hold women back at work and in our homes ‚Äî they're also paid less. The least they can do is give us equal pay.

Moreover, studies confirm that while working moms face a "motherhood penalty," working dads get a "fatherhood premium."

See here: https://t.co/O4KQvix1ZH

TLDR: The pay gap is not a gender pay gap (it's a mom pay gap).

Working moms, on average, earn just 58 cents for every dollar working dads earn. And that gap is even wider for Black moms, Latina moms, and certain communities of Asian American & Pacific Islander moms.

Today is #MomsEqualPayDay, and it should be getting WAY more attention.

When we talk about the pay gap, the reality is that the true pay gap is between childless people and moms, and single moms in particular.
#Tiafoe https://t.co/pLs1nLrIQP

Speaking of which, this Thursday is #MomsEqualPayDay, and it's a good time to remind everyone that the largest pay gap in the workforce is actually not between men and women ‚Äî it's between childless women and moms. That's what we call the motherhood penalty.

The pay gap is so built in to our workplaces that even the absolute biggest women in Hollywood face pay discrimination. And as with every industry, I'm sure the gap gets even wider for moms in entertainment.

All this to say, we can end gun violence AND we can end police violence without compromising one for the other. Kids depend on it.

Like I said, moms are the best multitaskers I know. Let's show Congress how it's done. Start by following the lead of Black and brown moms.
Ever heard of the school-to-prison pipeline? That's what more police in schools will contribute to ‚Äî not decrease school shootings.

The research shows that police in schools (known as school resource officers, or SROs) do not reduce school shootings. But they DO increase suspensions, expulsions, and arrests of students ‚Äî and disproportionately students of color (including girls).
https://t.co/QlPvloVz9f

After every school shooting, there's always a push to add more police in schools.

We HAVE to listen to Black and brown mothers when they warn that more police will make children *less* safe. And the data backs this up.

Moms can multitask better than anyone. And the same should be true for how we approach our advocacy.

Here's what's on my mind in the aftermath of #Uvalde, #Buffalo, and 2 years to the day since #GeorgeFloyd was murdered.

This moment is yet another example of how in the U.S. we put expectations on mothers to do something for their children, but then we make it hard as hell to succeed at it.

So bottom line as we continue to have these conversations around the formula shortage, let's remember that it's about choice ‚Äî a mother's individual choice ‚Äî and it‚Äôs also about what we consider work.

Nihal and I wanted to give both our kids breast milk because we have autoimmune disease and allergies, and breast milk is supposed to help with fighting them. What Amber did for our family was WORK, so I paid her for the labor she was undertaking to give Sai breast milk.

When Sai was born, I couldn't breastfeed him because he was born through surrogacy. Our incredible surrogate, Amber, who is a nurse in the ER, pumped and shipped breast milk every week to Sai while navigating all the other challenges of the pandemic.

For many single moms, moms of color, low-income moms, and disabled moms, the choice is made for them. And it‚Äôs not as if formula feeding doesn‚Äôt have its own challenges. But what if we treated breastfeeding‚Äîand formula feeding‚Äîas the work that it is?

But we still don't make it easy for those who make that choice. We judge them, we even sometimes shame them if they do or if they don't.

And even with its challenges, having the freedom and flexibility to breastfeed is still a privilege in the U.S.
Back in 2015, there weren't pump rooms in airports or in many offices, or CEOs breastfeeding in the @nytimes. Since then, we‚Äôve come a long way in normalizing breastfeeding.

It was a job in addition to the full-time job I had as CEO of @GirlsWhoCode. Everything about my schedule revolved around finding the time to feed Shaan. So the requirement I made for doing the profile was to show me breastfeeding.

When @nytimes emailed me 7 years ago to do a profile about what I do on Sundays, I made sure to talk about breastfeeding, and yes, I requested they use a photo of me nursing Shaan. Because you know what I did on Sundays in 2015? I was breastfeeding a newborn. https://t.co/b0ariGFuV0

It was a glimpse into a world that those daughters will help build ‚Äî and hopefully, my sons will, too: a world where moms can‚Äôt always be there or get it all right, and their kids love them all the more for it.

The moment at Judge Jackson‚Äôs hearing that made me most hopeful for our country wasn‚Äôt anything she said. It was the way her daughters looked at her ‚Äî with unequivocal love and pride and understanding.

Thank you to @Yale's senior class committee picking me and for trusting me to send you out in this world as it is today with all its beauty and all of its complexity.

See you in May, my friends.

So for me, this is huge. And it's huge because of the obligation I feel to those graduates when I step on the stage. This is @Yale's first in-person graduation since the pandemic. I have been working on this speech for six months and I promise you that I won't let you down.

I literally didn't know anyone who went to Yale. I mean, I'd heard from a temple mom there was some Indian kid who allegedly went, but I never met this person in IRL. To this day, I don't know if that was an Indian auntie pipe dream to make us do our homework or a real human.
As a working class brown kid from the Midwest, everyone I knew went to state school or community college (all great options).
My path to @Yale was not traditional, to say the least. I went to @YaleLawSch as a TRANSFER STUDENT. I applied 3 times before I got in. Ever since I was a kid, all I wanted was a Yale degree.

But I am a mom of 2 who has lived in the corner of her bedroom on Zoom for the past 2 years, and is obsessed with teaching girls to code and fighting for moms. And after the past 2 years of pandemic #MomLife, I and the 85 million other moms in the U.S. deserve a statue somewhere.

When President Salovey asked me late last winter, I almost fainted. I am not a former President, a famous media personality, a cabinet member, nor have I won the EGOT (I've been told I have a terrible voice, though I can dance).

So I never thought I would be saying this, but I am going to be @YALE UNIVERSITY'S 2022 CLASS DAY SPEAKER (Yale's equivalent of a commencement speaker).

...When I got pregnant I was the only woman partner in this law firm. And nobody said a word to me about being pregnant. I just kept getting bigger and bigger and bigger and you know walking down the hall to go to a meeting or whatever I was doing. Nobody said a word.

Overall, 71% of moms surveyed described being a working mom as ‚Äúvery challenging‚Äù during the pandemic. But perhaps the most jarring statistic we found is that 74% of moms surveyed have left the workforce, reduced their hours, or become self-employed in the last year. https://t.co/MCT7IoC8Ue

While the issues facing working moms aren‚Äôt new, what is new is that as we begin returning to work, employers have a once-in a-generation-opportunity to reimagine the future of work in a way that is inclusive, equitable, and values women‚Äôs labor.

We surveyed over 1,000 moms from different backgrounds and in different roles across the U.S., drew on hundreds of academic studies and articles, and interviewed dozens of experts to detail what companies need to do to build mom-friendly workplaces for the post-pandemic future.

In other words: the U.S. needs paid leave ‚Äî NOW. It is a matter of life and deaths for too many moms.

#MarshallPlanForMoms

And yes, there is a correlation.

In the U.S., 40% of maternal deaths occur in the 6 weeks following labor. Almost 20% occur between 6 weeks postpartum and 1 year.

Paid leave allows working moms the time they need to recover from childbirth.

Meanwhile, the U.S. ranks last among high-income nations in maternal mortality rates, with Black women accounting for a disproportionate percent of maternal deaths.

Black women are 2-3 x more likely than white women to die in childbirth or from pregnancy-related complications.

Only 20% of private sector workers had access to paid family leave in 2020.

And just 8% of workers in the bottom wage quartile had access to paid family leave in 2020, with Black and Latino people being less likely to work in jobs with paid leave.

Evergreen reminder that the U.S. is the ONLY high-income nation to not guarantee any form of paid maternity leave.

Motherhood is in crisis. It was in crisis mode long before the pandemic, and the past 15 months has only made things more difficult. 

I'll say it again: being a mom should not be THIS expensive. Being a mom should not be expensive. Period.

Time for a #MarshallPlanForMoms.
Meanwhile, the cost of living in the U.S. continues to rise as wages remain stagnant. Raising the minimum wage to $15 / hour would go a long way for so many moms who are in dire need of support.
And what about childcare? Well, the average U.S. family with a working mom pays about $13,000 in child care per year for kids under 5, according to @amprog.

Once the child is born, paid leave is a whole other issue. The U.S. is the ONLY high-income nation in the world that doesn't guarantee that new moms and parents will have paid leave after the birth of a child.

Let‚Äôs start with childbirth.

Labor costs, on average, are more than $4,500 per childbirth, even with insurance.

And the price of maternity and newborn surgeries has risen by 60% over the past decade.
Nearly 3 in 5 millennials without children say a reason they don‚Äôt have kids is because it is too expensive to raise them. And they‚Äôre not wrong!

Being a mom should not be this expensive. #MarshallPlanForMoms
